questions.text: Identify the organization that has the given emblem:

choices.text: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme
National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke

questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP).

Characteristics of NLEP emblem:

  • The lotus in the NLEP emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb, a normal forefinger, and the shape of a house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of leprosy.

NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Option A: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

Option C: Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS)

Option D: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not effective for disinfection of sputum of patients?
questions.solution:
Chlorhexidine is not used to disinfect sputum.

Sputum can be disinfected by:

  • Autoclaving or boiling - if a considerable amount of sputum is present (e.g. in TB hospitals)
  • 5% cresol - patients are asked to spit in a sputum cup half-filled with cresol
  • Burning - for samples received in gauze or paper handkerchiefs

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. 

A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.

Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.  

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the pathogenesis period of a disease?

choices.text: Recovery is seen in this period
Entry of causative agent is seen

questions.solution:
Primary prevention is not possible in the pathogenesis period of a disease. It can only be done in the period of pre-pathogenesis.

The two phases in the natural history of a disease include:

  • Period of pre-pathogenesis: It is before the onset of disease in humans. The disease agent has not entered the host, but the factors favouring the disease already exist. Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • Period of pathogenesis: It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death or disability. Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period. It isn't always characterised by the presence of disease symptoms as it also includes subclinical cases.

questions.text: While in a health camp, you notice a child with fever and rash. On subsequent history, you find out that similar symptoms occurred in her friend 6 days back. How will you epidemiologically categorise the child you examined?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the child is categorised as the index case. It is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.

The primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.  

A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case. 

A suspect case refers to a patient who has all the features of the disease but has not been diagnosed with it yet.

Note: There is no such term as tertiary case.

questions.text: Antigenic variation is most commonly seen with
questions.solution:
Type A influenza virus is most commonly seen to manifest antigenic variations hence causes pandemics. Influenza is caused by Orthomyxovirus type A, B, and C. Type A is the most common associated with pandemics, outbreaks and is responsible for most of the antigenic variation.
Antigenic shift – is due to complete change in the genetic makeup caused due to reassortment, sudden occurrence and can leads to pandemic
Antigenic drift – is a minor change in the genetic makeup caused due to point mutation leading to gradual changes and doesn’t lead to pandemics, but leads to sporadic cases.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is composed of OKA strain?
questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine is composed of live attenuated OKA strain.

Other options: 

Option A - Live attenuated RA 27/3 strain is used for the rubella vaccine.

Option C - Live attenuated SA 14-14-2 strain is used for the JE vaccine (Japanese encephalitis) which is based on a stable neuro-attenuated strain of the JE virus.

Option D - The Edmonston-Zagreb measles strain is used for the live attenuated measles vaccine used in India.

questions.text: Cross product ratio can be arrived from:
questions.solution:
Cross product ratio (Odds ratio) can be obtained from the case-control study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method to reduce confounding?
questions.solution:
Deletion is not a method to reduce confounding.

Methods to reduce confounding:

  • At the time of designing the study:
    • Randomization
    • Matching
    • Restriction
  • At the time of analysis:
    • Stratification
    • Statistical modelling like regression analysis, multivariate analysis and the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

questions.text: What is the temperature that has to be maintained for sterilization in the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a sterilizing hot air oven. The temperature to be maintained is 160° C for 2 hours.

Exposure to dry heat in a sterilizing hot air oven ensures the carbonization of organic material and the destruction of microorganisms and spores. The following combinations of temperature and duration of sterilization can be applied in hot air ovens:

  • 180°C for 30 mins
  • 170°C for 60 mins
  • 160⁰C for 2 hours

questions.text: Open vial policy is not applicable to which of the following vaccines?
questions.solution:
Open vial policy is not applicable for BCG and measles vaccines.

It is applicable for:

  • DPT
  • TT
  • Hepatitis B vaccine
  • OPV
  • Pentavalent vaccine
  • Rotavirus vaccine (New version with the VVM on the side)

Related Pearl: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40 year old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40 year old man

questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants to a country is an example of prospective screening.

Screening of disease is done to detect unrecognized disease or defect, in apparently healthy individuals, by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures.

The difference between prospective and prescriptive screening is given below:

  Prospective screening Prescriptive screening
Definition People screened for others benefit People screened solely for their own benefit
Essential purpose Disease control Case detection
Request for screening Specific request from the authority Request from physician
Example
  • Immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis syphilis, yellow fever, etc;
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits, sex workers.
  • Screening of blood donors.
  • Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism.
  • Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
  • Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus.

Note: Most common neonatal disease to be screened for is neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: What is the main drawback of polysaccharide-based vaccines?

choices.text: They cause severe pain at the injection site
The immune responses elicited are serotype specific
It cannot be conjugated with proteins to enhance immunogenicity
The rate of adverse reactions is very high

questions.solution:
Polysaccharide-based vaccines stimulate an antibody response against the surface polysaccharide of the pathogenic-capsulated bacteria. The polysaccharide structure varies not only between bacteria of different species but also between different strains within a single species. Thus, a limitation of these vaccines is that the immune responses are serotype-specific.

If these vaccines are conjugated with proteins, they are given the capability of eliciting a stronger immune response. Multivalent formulations of both polysaccharide-based vaccines and conjugated vaccines are required to achieve protection against multiple serotypes.

questions.text: Which of these vaccines is not covered in the programme mentioned below?
questions.solution:
The given logo represents Mission Indradhanush and it does not include the typhoid vaccine.

Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush. The Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB (BCG vaccine)
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • Haemophilus influenzae B (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese encephalitis

questions.text: Which medicine claims to be the world’s first organized body of medical knowledge?
questions.solution:
Chinese medicine claims to be the world's first organized body of medical knowledge.  It dates back to 2700 B.C. They are also considered to be the pioneers of immunization (used variolation against smallpox).

Modern Chinese medicine includes barefoot doctors and acupuncture.

questions.text: Endemic typhus is transmitted by _______
questions.solution:
Endemic typhus is caused by Flea.

Endemic typhus also termed Murine typhus or flea-borne typhus is caused by rickettsia typhi. It is transmitted by fleas and rats are reservoirs. The incubation period is 1–2 weeks. The Weil Felix reaction is positive in 2nd week. Tetracycline is the drug of choice. Rodent control is most important and is best done by BHC and malathion.

questions.text: The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is planning to study the natural history of COVID-19. Which of the following studies can be used?
questions.solution:
Longitudinal studies are useful to study the natural history of a disease.

It is also used to identify risk factors, and to find the incidence rate. In longitudinal studies, observations are repeated in the same population over a prolonged period of time by follow-up examinations. Their disadvantage is that they are difficult to organize and take a very long time.

questions.text: According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than _________.
questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than 1000.

The Factories Act, 1948 states the following regarding safety and welfare measures:

  • > 1000 workers – there should be a safety officer
  • > 500 workers – there should be a welfare officer
  • > 250 workers – a canteen should be provided
  • > 30 female workers- a crèche should be provided

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: An entomologist was studying a vector and the pathogen it transmits. He found that the pathogen underwent changes in number and morphology in the vector. What is this type of biological transmission called?
questions.solution:
This type of biological transmission where a pathogen undergoes a change in number and morphology in a vector is called cyclo-propagative transmission.

Malaria is a disease whose causative organism (Plasmodium sp.) undergoes cyclo-propagative transmission. In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in the Anopheles mosquito (vector).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: Identify the type of epidemic depicted from the following epidemic curve.
questions.solution:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image.

In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of time. It occurs within one incubation period of the disease.

Related Pearl: Epidemics and its Types

An epidemic is an occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness that is clearly in excess of normal expectancy. Its types include:

Common source epidemics

  • Single exposure or 'point source' epidemics
  • Multiple or continuous exposure epidemics

Propagated or progressive epidemics

  • Person to person
  • Arthropod vector
  • Animal reservoir

Slow or modern epidemics

  • Non-communicable diseases

questions.text: Which of the following is a quantitative method of management?
questions.solution:
Cost-benefit analysis is a quantitative method of management.

In this method, the economic benefits of any programme are compared with the costs incurred. The benefit of the programme is expressed in monetary units. The main drawback here is that the benefits of a health programme cannot always be expressed in monetary terms.

Management methods used in health programmes are either quantitative or based on behavioral sciences.

Methods based on behavioral sciences include: 

  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Quantitative methods include:

  • Cost-benefit analysis
  • Cost-effective analysis
  • Cost–accounting
  • Input-output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis - includes programme evaluation and review technique (PERT) and critical path method (CPM)
  • Planning–programming–budgeting system (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making

questions.text: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as the prevalence of :
questions.solution: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as a prevalence of < 1 per 10,000.

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector for Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus are the two vectors for Zika virus transmission.

Zika virus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus and the infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise.

A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations. Petechial rashes are not seen.

Complications: Guillian-Barre syndrome and microcephaly and intracranial calcification in infants born to mothers infected with Zika virus. Pregnant women should consider postponing travel to areas where Zika virus transmission is ongoing.

Diagnosis:  

  • Trioplex Real-Time RT-PCR (rRT-PCR) assay
  •  Zika MAC-ELISA.

questions.text: You are volunteering in a vaccination camp. You perform a shake test before administering a particular vaccine. Which of the following is checked by this test?
questions.solution:
The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

  • A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.
  • Both are shaken after thawing and the rate of sedimentation is compared.
  • If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.

Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive. These include vaccines against:

  • Diphtheria
  • Tetanus
  • Pertussis
  • Haemophilus influenza type b (Liquid )
  • Hepatitis B

questions.text: A baby is brought with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting. The weight of the baby is 12 kgs. What is the estimated amount of fluid to be replaced in 4 hours?
questions.solution:
According to the guidelines of ORS by WHO, a child with a weight of 11-15.9 kg has to be treated with 800-1200 ml of ORS solution within the first 4 hours.

Guidelines for oral rehydration therapy (for all ages) during the first four hours by WHO:

Age  Under 4 months 4-11 months 1-2 yrs 2-4yrs 5-14 yrs 15 yrs or over
Weight (kg) under 5  5-7.9 8-10.9 11-15.9 16-29.9 30 or over
ORS solution (ml) 200-400 400-600 600-800 800-1200 1200-2200 2200-4000

The patient's age should be used if weight is not known.

The approximate amount of ORS required in ml may also be calculated by 75 x body weight (kg).

questions.text: A researcher is planning to study the etiology of certain painful idiopathic peripheral neuropathies. Which of the following study methods shall he choose?
questions.solution:
Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology.

Related Pearl: Descriptive Epidemiology

Descriptive Epidemiology

  • Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology.
  • Steps
    • Defining the population to be studied
    • Defining the disease to be studied
    • Describing the disease by time, place, and person
      • Measurement of the disease by cross sectional or longitudinal study
      • Comparing with known indices
      • Formulation of an etiological hypothesis
  • Uses
    • Provides data of magnitude of disease load in community
    • Provides clues to disease etiology
    • Provides background data for health planning
    • Contributes to research by describing the disease

questions.text: Choose the correct linear regression equation.
questions.solution:
The regression equation is given as expected value of y = a + bx, where a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.

Related Pearl: Regression

When two variables are correlated, the value of one of the variables can be predicted from the value of the other using regression techniques.

  • Independent variable: The variable from which the other variable is calculated.
  • Dependent variable: The variable for which the value is calculated.

Types of regression:

1. Simple linear regression

  • In this, the value of one variable (y) is used to predict the value of another variable (x).
  • The regression equation is used for this purpose. It gives a straight-line relationship between the two variables.
  • It is given by the equation y = a + bx, where, a is a constant called the intercept constant and b is the regression coefficient.
  • The intercept constant is the point where the Y-axis is intercepted by the regression line. 

 2. Multiple linear regression

  • In this, more than one variable is used to predict the expected value of another variable (y).
  • Here, the expected value of y = a + b1x1 + b2x2…..bnxn where b1 and b2…..bn represent different regression coefficients and x1, x2…….xn represents the known variables.

 3. Logistic regression

  •  In some situations, we are not interested in a numerical outcome (like risk, etc) but we want a nominal or categorical one (like death/survival, developing a disease/not developing a disease)
  • Here, the relationship between the variables will not be a linear one as the outcome from survival to death in relationship with the risk factor can change suddenly. Thus these outcomes are represented by 0 and 1.
  • Using a mathematical logistic function we can transform linear regression data, such that the values of a variable y are limited to the range of 0 to 1, which would give us the probability of y occurring for the given values of variable x.

questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a country is best given as __________
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

The main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor, and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia-related complications, etc.

In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue?
questions.solution:
The absence of fever for 12 hours is not a criterion for the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue. Fever should be absent for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs in order to discharge a patient recovering from dengue.

Criteria for discharge of patients recovering from dengue:

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretic drugs
  • Platelet count >50,000/mm3
  • Return of appetite
  • Adequate urine output
  • Visible clinical improvement
  • Minimum of 2-3 days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion or ascites

questions.text: A new drug called Lumoxiti is effective for curing Hairy cell leukemia. Which of the following is true about the prevalence and incidence of the disease?

choices.text: No change in incidence and increase in prevalence
No change in incidence but decrease in prevalence

questions.solution:
In this case, the new drug is effective for the treatment of that disease, so the duration of the disease is decreased thereby decreasing the prevalence of the disease. There is no change in the incidence of the disease.

Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence, and duration of illness. If the population is stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as:

P = I X D

(I - Incidence and D - Mean duration)

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of the physical quality of life index (PQLI)?
  1. Infant mortality rate
  2. Life expectancy at birth

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is not a method of direct transmission of diseases.

It is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.

Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.

These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

Droplet transmission, vertical transmission, and contact with soil are methods of direct transmission of diseases.

Differences between droplet and droplet nuclei are summarised below:

DROPLET NUCLEI  DROPLET 
Indirect transmission Direct transmission
It is the residue from evaporated droplets It is produced while coughing, sneezing, talking
<5microns in diameter ≥5 microns in diameter
No need for close contact for transmission Requires closeness and direct contact for transmission
Diseases transmitted: chickenpox, measles etc. Diseases transmitted: diphtheria, meningococcal meningitis etc.

Related Pearl: Modes of Transmission of Communicable Diseases

questions.text: Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for?
questions.solution:
Nischay kit provided by the government to ASHA under NRHM is used for early pregnancy testing.

Nishchay is a home-based Pregnancy Test Kit (PTK) that was launched under NRHM across the country and was later anchored with the Family Planning Division. The pregnancy test kits are being made available at the sub-center level and are also distributed to ASHA.

These pregnancy test kits are supplied free of cost and are home-based and easy to use. It facilitates early detection and also decision-making for the outcomes of pregnancy. Helping to detect pregnancy as early as one week after the missed period, provides an early opportunity for medical termination of pregnancy, thus saving lives lost to unsafe abortions.

Note: NIKSHAY is an online tool launched by the government for RNTCP to monitor tuberculosis in the country.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is least likely to be associated with malignancies?
questions.solution:
HPV 6 and 11 are considered low-risk subtypes and are associated mainly with genital warts (condyloma acuminata) and respiratory papillomatosis in both genders.

HPV 16 and 18 are considered high-risk subtypes and are associated with cancer cervix and pre-cancerous cervical lesions. There is also evidence linking HPV 16 and 18 with cancers of the anus, vulva, vagina, penis, and oropharynx.

Important agents associated with malignant conditions:

  • HHV-8 (mainly), cytomegalovirus - Kaposi’s sarcoma
  • Epstein-Barr virus - Burkitt’s lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • HPV 16 and 18 - Cancer cervix
  • HBV and HCV - Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Schistosoma - Bladder carcinoma

questions.solution:

questions.text: In the iceberg phenomenon of disease, which of the following does not represent the submerged portion of the iceberg?
questions.solution:
Epidemiologically, the iceberg phenomenon of disease, diagnosed cases are represented by the floating tip of the iceberg.

The iceberg phenomenon of disease is related to the spectrum of disease. The water surface is the line of demarcation between the apparent and inapparent infections.

The submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of diseases like asymptomatic, latent, and undiagnosed cases. Screening is done to identify these cases.

questions.text: What is the best parameter to measure air pollution?
questions.solution:
One of the best parameters to measure air pollution is sulphur dioxide.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Air pollutants:

Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide Incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulfur dioxide

Colorless gas
Sharp odor
Combustion of sulfur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc
Main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources
Carbon dioxide Increase in a global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog
Cadmium From volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc
Hydrogen sulfide Waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc
Ozone Ground-level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen Most common form is nitric oxide
From coal burning, road traffic, and electricity generation
Affects the lungs adversely
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc
Carcinogenic and mutagenic
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter
Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon, and water.
Common indoor air pollutants

From coal or fuel combustion

Include CO, PAHs, nitrogen and sulfur oxides, pesticides, and other biological pollutants


Radon, lead, asbestos are formed from construction materials, paints, and demolition

Effects of indoor air pollution:

  • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
  • Stroke
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • COPD
  • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
  • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight

Indicators of air pollution:

  • Sulfur dioxide - one of the best indicator of air pollution
  • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
  • Grit and dust measurement 
  • The co-efficient of haze - assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosols in the air
  • Air pollution index - measure of pollution severity
  • Suspended particle matter (SPM) 

In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a wrist drop, severe colicky abdominal pain, and constipation. His peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the commonest mode of occupational exposure to the compound responsible?
questions.solution:
The clinical background and the image showing basophilic stippling are suggestive of lead poisoning. Inhalation is the most common route of occupational exposure to lead.

Lead poisoning may occur by:

  • Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead
  • Ingestion via contaminated hands or when small amounts of lead trapped in the upper respiratory tract are swallowed.
  • Absorption through the skin

Painters exposed to lead-based paints usually develop plumbism (lead poisoning). The clinical features of lead poisoning include abdominal colic, constipation, loss of appetite, a blue line on the gums (Burtonian line), basophilic stippling of red cells, anemia, wrist drop, and foot drop. CNS symptoms like insomnia, headache, mental confusion, delirium, may also be seen.

Coproporphyrin levels in urine (CPU) are useful in screening. Measurement of blood and urine lead levels should be done for diagnosis.

Chelation with oral DMSA, calcium EDTA, and dimercaprol are treatment modalities. Correction of iron, calcium, zinc, and calcium deficiencies should be done. Vitamin C is a weak chelating agent.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text:
In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease?
  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive 1000 50
Test negative 500 3450
Total 1500 3500
questions.solution:
Prevalence is given by the formula: 

In this scenario, the number of cases: 1000+500 = 1500.

Total population: 5000

Prevalence= 1500/5000 × 100 = 30%.

questions.text: A paradoxical carrier is defined as:

choices.text: A person who sheds pathogens during incubation period
A carrier who acquired pathogen from another carrier
A person who acquired pathogen from patient
A patient who became a carrier

questions.solution:
A paradoxical carrier is a carrier that acquired a pathogen from another carrier.

Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. 

Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. 

Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.

questions.text: Project MONICA is related to:
questions.solution:
Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

It stands for multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different countries.

World Heart Day is celebrated every year on the 29th of September. The theme for World Heart Day 2021 is "Use Heart to Connect".

World Heart Day 2023 theme was 'Use Heart, Know Heart'.

World Heart Day 2024 theme is 'ABCD- AnyBody Can Die'.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most universally accepted health status indicator?
questions.solution:
Infant mortality rate (IMR) is the most universally accepted health status indicator of the whole population and of the socio-economic conditions in which they live.

Infant mortality rate (IMR)= Number of deaths in the first year of life/Number of live births x 1000

It is a sensitive indicator of the availability, utilisation, and effectiveness of health care.

questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of the atorvastatin drug. She measures the initial cholesterol levels of 50 patients. After a month's treatment, she measures the cholesterol level again. Which of the following tests will she use to test the statistical significance of the change in the cholesterol level?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the variable (cholesterol level) is quantitative. Moreover, the comparison is being done before and after the treatment (dependent). Hence, a paired t test will be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding tracking of blood pressure?

choices.text: BP increases with age in all individuals
BP falls steadily in the elderly
Hypertensive children become hypotensive as they grow
BP of hypotensive children tends to remain low in adult life

questions.solution:
If the blood pressure of individuals is followed up over years from early childhood to adult life, low blood pressures tend to remain low and high blood pressures become higher as the individuals grow older. This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure is described as tracking.

This is helpful in identifying children and adolescents who are at risk of developing hypertension in the future.

Although blood pressure is known to increase with age in both sexes, some communities have been identified whose mean blood pressure does not rise with age. This is because their salt intake and calorie consumption are at a subsistence level.

questions.text: Chandlers Index is used in epidemiological studies of_____
questions.solution:
Chandlers index is used to identify the importance of hookworm infestation as a public health problem in a community. It is calculated based on the average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool:

  • <200: no significance
  • 200-250: the potential danger
  • 250-300: minor public health problem
  • >300: major public health problem

questions.text: You have been sent to an area to study the ongoing typhoid epidemic. When will you declare the area to be free of the epidemic?
questions.solution:
The area will be declared free of the typhoid epidemic when no new cases are reported for 28 days. 

An area is declared free of an epidemic when there are no cases reported for twice the incubation period of the disease since the last case.

The incubation period of typhoid is 14 days. So, in the given scenario, the area will be declared free of the epidemic when no new cases are reported for twice the incubation period i.e., 14 x 2 = 28 days.

questions.text: A polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae has 23 serotypes. In which of the following patients is this vaccine most beneficial?

choices.text: A patient with sickle cell disease
A patient with recurrent otitis media

questions.solution:
The polysaccharide vaccine against Streptococcus pneumoniae (PPSV-23) is most beneficial for patients with sickle cell disease.

S. pneumoniae is an encapsulated organism that is detected by the spleen and is removed. However, in sickle cell disease, the sickled cells block the vessels in the spleen which results in splenic infarction. This hyposplenism results in an increased risk of pneumococcal infection. Hence, pneumococcal vaccine (PPSV-23) is given to these patients as a prophylactic measure to reduce this risk.

questions.text:
The incubation period for measles in a group of 25 children was calculated. Following findings were recorded. What is the standard error?

Standard deviation = 2.

Median incubation period = 8 days.
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the standard error = 0.4.

The formula for standard error:

SE = Standard deviation/√sample size = 2/√25 = 2/5 = 0.4

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: A researcher conducts a study among smokers. He finds that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. This is indicative of:
questions.solution:
The study where the researcher finds that 80% of lung cancer cases are due to cigarette smoking is indicative of attributable risk.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease between an exposed group and an unexposed group.

It is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure. It also refers to the amount of disease that could be eliminated if the exposure is controlled or eliminated. It reflects the impact of public health programs in the prevention of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Incidence of a disease refers to the number of new cases occurring in a population in a given period of time.

Option B: Relative risk refers to the ratio of incidence of the disease among the exposed and the incidence of disease among the unexposed population. It establishes the strength of association between the disease and the suspected causative factor.

Option D: Population attributable risk refers to the incidence of the disease in the total population minus the incidence of disease among the population unexposed to the causative factor. It indicates the incidence of disease that could be prevented in the total population if the suspected causative factor was eliminated. 

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of vitamin A to be administered to this child?
questions.solution:
2 lakh IU of vitamin A should be administered to a 2-year-old child with vitamin A deficiency.

Dosage of vitamin A in children:

  • 50,000 IU for children less than 6 months of age
  • 1 lakh IU for children between 6 months to 12 months of age
  • 2 lakh IU for children above 12 months of age. 

These doses of vitamin A are to be administered on days 1, 2 and 14 for the treatment of vitamin A deficiency.

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

questions.text: Surveillance data of an endemic disease reveals that most of the children in the area had been affected and had to be hospitalised. However, most of the adults remained asymptomatic carriers. Which category does this disease belong to?
questions.solution:
The disease in question belongs to the category of holoendemic diseases. In such diseases, a higher prevalence and pathogenic response are seen among the children in an area. The adults tend to be either asymptomatic carriers or show reduced damage by the disease process. E.g, malaria.

An endemic disease is a disease that is present constantly in a population or in a given area without importation from outside. E.g, kala-azar in Bihar.

A hyperendemic disease is a disease that is constantly present at high incidence and prevalence among all groups in a population. E.g, dengue in India.

A syndemic is the aggregation of two or more concurrent or sequential epidemics or disease clusters in a population with biological interactions, which exacerbate the prognosis and burden of disease. It is also known as a synergistic epidemic.

Note: Quasiendemic is not a term used in infectious disease epidemiology.

questions.text: A mother brought a 2 month old child with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting. As a part of management, you advise her regarding vaccination for rotavirus.  Which is the false statement regarding the same?

choices.text: Rotarix is administered in 2 oral doses.
It cannot be given in an immunocompromised child.
The first dose of Rotarix is contraindicated for infants <12 weeks.
It is not a part of catchup vaccination programmes due to its risk of intussusception.

questions.solution:
The first dose of the Rotarix vaccine is contraindicated for infants > 12 weeks of age due to the potential risk of intussusception. Hence, it is not a part of catch-up immunization programs as the age is difficult to ascertain in such programs.

Rotavirus vaccines are live, attenuated, and are administered orally. So, it is not given to an immunocompromised child.

questions.text: Which sequence of infection poses the highest risk of dengue hemorrhagic fever?
questions.solution:
The DENV-1 --> DENV-2 sequence of infection is associated with the highest risk of dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF).

Multiple infections with different serotypes of the dengue virus lead to severe forms of dengue such as DHF/DSS. The first infection probably sensitizes the patient, while the second infection with a different serotype appears to produce immunological catastrophe.

  • DENV-1 --> DENV-2 - 500-fold risk (compared to primary infection alone)
  • DENV-3 --> DENV-2 - 150-fold risk
  • DENV-4 --> DENV-2 - 50-fold risk 

Dengvaxia is the WHO endorsed first-ever vaccine for dengue fever, effective against serotypes 1, 2, 3 and 4. It is currently licensed in 20 countries. It is approved for use in individuals 9 - 16 years of age with laboratory-confirmed previous dengue infection (seropositive) and living in endemic areas.

questions.text: According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than:
questions.solution:
Three key clinical signs are used to assess a sick child with cough or difficult breathing:

  • Respiratory rate (RR): distinguishes children who have pneumonia from those who do not. Children are classified as pneumonia if: 
    • > 50/min RR for infants 2 months to 12 months
    • > 40/min RR for children 12 months to 5 years of age
  • Lower chest wall indrawing indicates severe pneumonia
  • Stridor indicates those with severe pneumonia requiring hospital admission.

The following image gives the IMNCI classification for cough/difficulty in breathing in children.

Signs of severe pneumonia are :

  • Not able to drink
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Convulsions
  • Lethargic or unconscious
  • Stridor in a calm child
  • Severe malnutrition

questions.text: The condition seen in image starts to occur at intake levels of ________ of the offending agent.
questions.solution:
The image shows mottling of teeth seen in Fluorosis. It starts to occur at intake levels of 1.5 mg/L of fluoride. 

Fluorosis seen with corresponding levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: 1.5 mg/L
  • Skeletal fluorosis: 3-6 mg/L
  • Crippling fluorosis: >10 mg/L

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about chickenpox?
  1. It is caused by HHV 3
  2. The scab is infective
  3. A killed vaccine is used for prophylaxis
  4. The secondary attack rate is 85%
  5. The virus stays latent in the sensory ganglion
questions.solution:
Chickenpox is caused by the human herpes virus-3 (varicella-zoster virus). It remains latent in the sensory ganglion. Reactivation of the virus can cause shingles.

The secondary attack rate of chickenpox is very high, 85% (range 61%–100%).

The characteristic infective vesicle, surrounded by an erythematous halo, is described as a dewdrop on a rose petal. The scab of chickenpox is not infective.

The vaccine given for chickenpox prophylaxis is live attenuated vaccine.

questions.text: Free and combined chlorines in water are separately identified by:
questions.solution:
• Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both combined and free chlorines in water separately.
  • Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorines together.
  • Chloronomes are devices used to regulate dose of chlorine gas used for disinfection.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: The Mid Day Meal Programme aims to supplement:
questions.solution:
Under the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, supplementary nutrition provided must cover at least 1/2 of total daily protein requirement and 1/3rd of total daily energy requirement of children in schools.

The MDM scheme is also called School Lunch Programme and has been operational since 1961 in India. Currently, it functions under the broad coverage of the Minimum Needs Programme.

Some other principles of the MDM are:

  • The meal provided under the MDM should only be a supplement and not a substitute for home diets.
  • The cost of meals should be reasonably low.
  • The meal should be easy to cook in schools.
  • Locally available foods must be used, for as far as possible.
  • The menu should be regularly changed to avoid monotony.

Note: In September 2021, the Mid-Day Meal Scheme was renamed PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease.

Note:

Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure __________
questions.solution:
The instrument given above is globe thermometer which is used to measure mean radiant temperature.

Other options : 

Option A - Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers are the most widely used instrument
  • Sling psychrometer/Whirling psychrometer:  It is used to measure the relative humidity

Option C - The air velocity is measured by an instrument called the "anemometer".

Option D - Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time. It contains both mercury and alcohol.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A meta-analysis is being performed to evaluate the relationship between obesity and endometrial carcinoma. Which among the following is false regarding this technique?

choices.text: File drawer effect can be seen here
It increases the statistical power  by increasing sample size
Apples and oranges effect can be seen here
Its validity does not depend on the quality of the systematic review

questions.solution:
The validity of the meta-analysis depends on the quality of the systematic review.

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

questions.text: Adjuvant used in DPT is:
questions.solution:
Adsorbed DPT vaccine has aluminium phosphate or hydroxide as the mineral carrier or adjuvant, which is the most advocated preparation for immunization in infants.

DPT vaccine is a combined vaccine against diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus. It should be stored at 2 to 8 degree Celsius.

Three doses are usually given for primary immunization, intramuscularly, at 4 weeks apart. Boosters are given at 1 ½ to 2 years and then at 5 to 6 years. Fever and mild local reactions are common post-immunization.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child developed sore throat and difficulty in swallowing and mild fever. On examination, the clinical picture shown below is seen. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: Its administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.solution:
The image shows a dirty white pseudomembrane classic of diphtheria. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 37 is not a contraindication. 

Precautionary measures are taken when the temperature is above 40 degrees, but it is not considered a contraindication for subsequent doses of DPwT.

Anaphylaxis is a contraindication for subsequent vaccination with diphtheria, pertussis, or tetanus vaccine. Encephalopathy following vaccination is a contraindication for pertussis vaccine. DT is given for successive doses.

Events such as inconsolable cry, fever more than 40.5°C, seizures with or without fever are considered as precautions, and not contraindications for DTwP.

The cellular component of pertussis is not recommended after 7 years.

  • Unvaccinated child 5-7 years: Give DPT 1, 2 and 3 at 1-month intervals. Administer booster dose of DPT at a minimum of 6 months
    after administering DPT-3 up to the age of 7 years.
  • Unvaccinated child above 7 years: Administer Tdap (Tetanus and diphtheria toxoids and acellular pertussis) at 0, and Td (Tetanus, Diphtheria vaccine) at 1 and 6 months, respectively.

The adult dose of diphtheria toxoid is almost 12 times lesser in comparison with the pediatric dosage.

Note: IAP guidelines state that "temperature more than >40.5°C is a precaution and not contraindication". Park's 27th Ed states that "temperature above 40°C is a contraindication to DPT". This topic is controversial, however, IAP guidelines are commonly followed by practitioners.

questions.text: You advise a reproductive age woman to vaccinate against HPV. What is this type of prevention called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of immunisation is an example of primary prevention.

Primary prevention is an action taken before the onset of disease. This reduces the possibility of disease occurrence. Hence, immunization is a form of primary prevention, through specific protection.

Examples of primary prevention include immunization, sanitation, solid and liquid waste management etc.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

Level

Primordial

Primary

Secondary

Tertiary

Phase of disease

Underlying socio-economic & environmental conditions leading to causation
