questions.text: In a group of 50 adult males, the mean height is 170 cm. The standard deviation is 2.5 cms. How many will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm, if the distribution is normal?
questions.solution:
17 men will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.

In this case,

S.D = 2.5 cm, mean = 170 cm

170 + 2.5 = 172.5 cm, 170 – 2.5 cm = 167.5 cm

Hence 68% men will have height between 167.5 cm and 172.5 cms. And 34% men will have height between 170 cm and 172.5 cms.

34/100 × 50 = 17 men will have height between 170 cms and 172.5 cms. 

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: You have witnessed your neighbor being bitten by a rabid dog. You should advise him to wash the wound with soap and water for a minimum of:
questions.solution:
Following dog bites, the bite wound should be washed with soap under running tap water for 15 minutes.

Local treatment of the bite wound is essential for the prevention of rabies and can reduce the infection rate by up to 80%. The following steps must be followed:

  • Cleansing: Washing under running water with soap or irrigation with a catheter in case of deep wounds
  • Chemical agent: Alcohol or tincture /0.01% aqueous solution of iodine or povidone-iodine is effective for inactivation of residual virus
  • Suturing: Must be done only following 24-48 hours if necessary, under the cover of rabies immunoglobulin locally and minimal stitches
  • Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures when indicated

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: Results of various studies carried out to study the role of smoking in breast cancer are plotted below. Identify the plot.
questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis.

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called as?
questions.solution:
Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C).

Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis.

Diagnosis of a disease before the critical point has a good outcome and reduces the severity by reversing the disease process. Diagnosis beyond the critical point treatment would be unsuccessful and/or permanent damage would have occurred.

Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis. That is conditions with a long lead time.

Generation time is defined as the interval of time between the onset of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman enquires about ways she can reduce her risk of coronary artery disease. Which of the following dietary modifications would you suggest?

choices.text: Reduction of salt intake to less than 10g per day
Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intake
Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake
Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100 mg/1000 kcal energy intake

questions.solution:
Limiting the consumption of saturated fats to less than 10% of total energy intake is recommended for the prevention of coronary artery disease.

The WHO'S Expert Committee suggested certain dietary modifications for the prevention of coronary artery disease. These include:

  • Reduction of the total fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day
  • Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less

questions.text: Which agency of the UN gives funds for technical assistance and has the following as part of its logo?
questions.solution:
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) is an agency of the UN that gives funds for technical assistance. It has the following logo.  

Its main objective is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources to their potential. 

Some other agencies of the UN include:

  • UNESCO - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
  • UNEP - United Nations Environment Programme
  • UNHCR - United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman is rushed to the hospital with labor pains at 34 weeks of gestation. She did not attend any prior antenatal visits. On further evaluation, she is found to be positive for HbsAg. Which of the following should be administered to the newborn after delivery?

choices.text: Immunoglobulin, followed by vaccine 1 month later

questions.solution:
The simultaneous administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and hepatitis B vaccine is more efficacious than HBIG alone for the prevention of the carrier state in newborn babies of HBV-positive mothers.

HBIG does not interfere with the antibody response to the hepatitis B vaccine. This combined procedure is ideal both for postexposure prophylaxis of persons accidentally exposed to blood known to contain hepatitis B virus and for the prevention of the carrier state in the newborn babies of carrier mothers.

HBIG (0.05–0.07 mL/kg) IM 

  • As early as possible, preferably within 24 hours of exposure

Hepatitis B vaccine (20 mcg/1.0 mL), IM

  • 1st dose: within 7 days of exposure
  • 2nd and 3rd dose: at one and six months, respectively
